repnme.cdata!:
Ivory Coast - Feeder Road and Highway
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Feeder Road and
            Highway Maintenance Project for the Ivory Coast was
            unsatisfactory. The project only partly achieved its main
            objectives, institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was less than satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, since
            feeder roads and maintenance projects that are scattered
            over large areas of a country require extensive and
            time-consuming supervision, the Bank should only approve
            such projects if it is willing to commit the necessary staff
            resources to oversee them on a continuing basis. Second, the
            limitations of executing works by force account need to be
            assessed more realistically. Third, the consultant's
            contract should have covered all the project works. Fourth,
            design standards, plans, and specifications should be
            prepared and agreed upon for force account works before they
            are allowed to start. Fifth, clear cut accounting and
            auditing controls should be set up at appraisal. Finally,
            the organization for follow-up maintenance on works
            completed should be agreed upon before commencing works.

repnme.cdata!:
Ivory Coast - Feeder Road and Highway
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would be carried out from
            1978 to 1981 and consist of a 3-1/2 year program for the
            improvement and maintenance of feeder roads and betterment
            of primary and secondary roads covering about 50 and 40
            percent respectively of the ongoing programs in these areas;
            construction of regional workshops; purchase of equipment;
            248 man-months of technical assistance for staff training,
            planning, implementing and monitoring the feeder road
            improvement and maintenance programs and preparation of a
            study to analyze the subsidy and taxation system for freight transport.
